DOC.HEAD: Forest Agency Turns to Goats to Control Vegetation
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Forest Service will try using goats instead of herbicides to control vegetation in the Ouachita National Forest. Fifty billy goats will graze on 20 acres in the first year of the four-year project on the north side of the Blue Ouachita Mountain near the north fork of the Ouachita River. The goats will graze annually from April to October. Using goats has ``the connotation of being a little bit weird and off-the-wall idea,'' said Jerry Ingersoll, forester for the Jessieville Ranger District. ``And it's certainly got some risk involved. We don't know whether or not it will work, really.'' Among the unknown factors, he said, is whether the goats will eat only the hardwoods and leave the pines. Ingersoll is part of a Forest Service team that will oversee the project, a joint effort with the American Institute for Goat Research at Langston University in Oklahoma. Dogs will protect the goats, all castrated adults, from predators and an electric fence will keep them within the area.
